Key Arguments: The legislation undermines freedom of speech, which is essential for democracy.
No single entity, including ACMA, should be considered the 'oracle of truth' as truth is subjective and can change over time.
The government has a poor track record of distinguishing between good information and misinformation, often suppressing divergent opinions.
The proposed amendment adds unnecessary bureaucracy and resembles a 'Ministry of Truth' from George Orwell's 'Nineteen Eighty-Four'.
The legislation is perceived as a method of political control rather than a genuine effort to protect Australians.
Notable Quotes: 'I may disagree with what you have to say but I will defend to the death your right to say it.'
No one person, no one entity has a monopoly on the truth.
The concept of what is proposed in this amendment comes dangerously close to morphing into the 'Ministry of Truth' as described by George Orwell in his book 'Nineteen Eighty-Four'.
This amendment has too many shades of the fascist regimes of the first half of the twentieth century in Europe that our parents lived through.
